comments.text:
+David Quintana the TPP has always been secret, there have been leaks from 
people brave enough to stand up for all of us to get word out about it, all 
partner countries have been blocked from reading it. What makes you think 
the text of it has been available?

Australia and New Zealand use a company that negotiates the best deals for 
their citizens' medication from American pharmaceuticals this combined size 
gives them power to negotiate, (think of how a supermarket negotiates for 
low prices from suppliers to pass on to  its customers based on its buying 
power). Under TPP this would be made illegal. That would likely lead to a 
4x increase in price for medicine.

Corporations are completely different from how they were originally set up 
in England and the United States (until two decades ago), they were 
originally limited to a few years for example. There were core restrictions 
and regulations that stopped them from corrupting the democratic and free 
market system by becoming too big, to politically influential and too 
anti-competitive; those were removed by successive presidents starting with 
Reagan - > Obama.

If Boeing, Amazon, Microsoft, Starbucks started polluting Seattle, your 
state's environmental protection laws would be illegal under the TPP. If 
China moved a sweat factory to Seattle to "employ" Seattle-ites, your 
States labor laws would be illegal. 

But yes, you will get to keep those minimum wage jobs.

comments.text:
-Insulting me or calling me names is not going to persuade the people that 
you need to persuade to promote your ideals.  The only people that will 
find your antics amusing will be people who live on the same bubble as you. 
 
-If the worst thing about my argument is my grammar I must have a great 
argument.  
-Nobody is dealing in secret.  The TPP was started by four countries that 
laid the base for the treaty.  In those four countries the treaty is 
working and anyone can read what laws those countries had to pass. 
-I don't understand why would you lose your healthcare in Australia.  Is 
true that if the treaty is applied drug companies will have more rights 
over the patents of some drugs but this companies did pay for the research. 
 
-If you live in the UK corporations control everything in your daily life. 
 Your country invented corporations on their current form.  
-Seattle and any city that is in the TPP region can benefit by creating 
more competitive markets, liberating capital and creating a set of rules 
that everyone has to abide by.  Seattle is a city that trades with Canada 
and Asia so any Pacific treaties will bring more work to the Port of 
Seattle and the Port of Tacoma.  We have many multinational companies and 
many local companies that service those companies so it will create more 
wealth for all of those companies.  People that service the middle class as 
is my case will benefit because this multinationals will hired more middle 
managers.  That means more clients for me.  
-I would like to see a more integrated Pacific region and the problem with 
this treaty is that it doesn't deal with the labor force.  I believe that 
unions and left groups should strive for including the labor into the 
treaty instead of fighting the treaty. If part of the rules where better 
controls on quality, much better oversight of labor rights and a more 
protection of individual rights this treaty would lift the biggest and most 
important region in the world to a new standard.

comments.text:
+Clay Peppard O, I understand that. Not all Republicans are conservatives, 
just lie not all Democrats are progressives. They're not mutually 
exclusive. That's why I'm a proud independent liberal-progressive, who 
doesn't appreciate the Democratic party's non-stop capitulation to the 
Right on substantive policy matters like the TPP.

The problem with the Trans-Pacific-Partnership, however, is that it does 
conform to what we today refer to as "conservatism." I understand that 
Paleoconservatives would be very much against free-trade deals (especially 
the kind that destroy American sovereignty), but they're so few and far 
between that it's almost useless to specify Paleoconservatives unless 
someone has already brought up that a certain type of conservative would be 
against free-trade deals.

The only other type of right-of-center ideology that I could think of that 
would be in favor of the TPP are certain types of libertarians and free 
market fundamentalists who like free trade deals, no matter what, because 
they've drunk the Free-Trade-Koolaid a long time ago-- and have this almost 
religious belief in the free market. These maybe considered, at the very 
least, fiscal conservatives in today's terms-- even though they unwittingly 
are promoting free market anarcho-Capitalism.
comments.author: BloodMoneyLLC
